title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Evergrande Resumes Residential Work; J&J Loses Bid to Pause Talc Suits; November Puerto Rico Confirmation Hearing Looms
text:
Construction sites near Evergrande's headquarters in Shenzhen. Photo: Aly Song/Reuters

Evergrande resumes residential work. China Evergrande Group, deeply in debt and trying to stave off collapse, said it has resumed work on more than 10 residential projects around Shenzhen, where it is based.

Chinese developer Modern Land fails to repay U.S. dollar bond. Modern Land (China) Co., a 21-year-old developer that focuses on green projects, failed to repay a $250 million dollar bond that matured Monday, adding to a string of missed payments by Chinese real-estate companies.

J&J loses first bid to pause talc suits. A bankruptcy judge denied an initial bid to pause thousands of talc lawsuits against Johnson & Johnson, setting up a November hearing that will scrutinize its use of the Texas two-step to try and settle suits via chapter 11. The judge called such transactions either "brilliant strategy" or "manifestly unfair," depending on your perspective.

Judge won't delay Puerto Rico confirmation hearing. A federal judge declined a request to delay Puerto Rico's Nov. 8 confirmation hearing after its Senate failed to pass key legislation needed to finalize its debt restructuring plan. The court ordered key stakeholders into mediation over the next few days.

Bankruptcy

Hertz said that, starting in early November and expanding through the end of the year, customers will be able to rent a Tesla Model 3 at airports and other locations in major U.S. markets and some cities in Europe. Photo: Cindy Ord/Getty Images

Hertz boosts Tesla stock. Hertz Global Holdings Inc. is ordering 100,000 vehicles from Tesla Inc. in order to bolster its rental car fleet with electric vehicles. Hertz is making the investment after emerging from chapter 11 with new ownership.

Scouts to turn over payment info. The bankrupt Boy Scouts of America failed to get approval from a judge to protect information discussed in mediation about procedures that could be used to determine how much compensation that abuse victims should receive.

Judge Laurie Selber Silverstein heard arguments last week in the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., about whether to shield various communications in mediation from discovery. The Scouts said disclosing such material could chill negotiations.

Insurers argued that the group has improperly withheld information based on a claim of mediation privilege. On Monday, the judge ruled that communications regarding trust distribution procedures are "discoverable."

—Becky Yerak

Limetree Bay bid deadline nears. Limetree Bay Refining is nearing a Monday evening deadline for buyers to submit their final bid proposals to purchase the bankrupt refinery.

Gregg Galardi, counsel to St. Croix Energy, an interested buyer, said in court on Monday that a workable bid to reopen the facility was proving "incredibly difficult" as the Environmental Protection Agency's permitting process was taking longer than expected.

He also noted that even if the presiding judge sought to transfer existing rights or services from Limetree to a successful buyer, the EPA could challenge certain of the judge's orders in appellate courts if it felt new agreements were needed with the refinery, further complicating and lengthening the sale process.

Limetree scheduled a status conference for Friday for an update on the sale process and on an ongoing dispute with its debtor-in-possession lender over a missed payment

—Alexander Saeedy

Pipeline Foods gets offer for Iowa assets. An auction of property and a grain storage facility in Atlantic, Iowa, generated a winning bid of $7.2 million in the bankruptcy of Pipeline Foods LLC.

The successful buyer, subject to court approval this week, is farmer-owned Landus Cooperative, based in Ames, Iowa. Landus has roughly 600 full-time employees in more than 60 communities and serves 7,000 farmer-owners, records show.

The backup bidder is Elite Octane LLC, with a $7 million offer. The initial bid had been roughly $4.4 million from Scoular Co. Also participating in the auction was 21st Century Cooperative, records show.

—Becky Yerak

Quotable

"From that perspective, the idea that corporate profits might win out over human tragedy is not something that sounds very palatable."

— Judge J. Craig Whitley discussing divisional mergers in the J&J talc case.

In Other News

USA Gymnastics cleared to poll creditors on $400 million sex abuse settlement. (Bloomberg Law)

The company behind a major oil spill off the coast of Orange County, Calif. could file for bankruptcy to address its liabilities. (Los Angeles Times)
